TITLE: ‚è∞ Save your time and schedule your notebook like a script!
TEXT:
‚è∞ Save your time and schedule your notebook like a script!


To schedule your Jupyter Notebook using Papermill in naas.ai, you just need to add this simple formulaüëá.

import naas
naas.scheduler.add(cron="0 * * * *") ‚Üê this cron argument is the standard syntax worldwide. It means every hour in that case.

Press play ‚ñ∂Ô∏è and your notebook will be sent to the Naas "‚ö°Ô∏èProduction folder".

Every time your notebook is executed, a record will be stored in this folder so you can access it if it fails.

Try now following this video: https://lnkd.in/erXctqWD

Thanks, Caleb Keller for the inspiration for my post!

Spread the open source love always üíö

#opensource #jupyternotebook #papermill #script #datascience #jobs #buildinpublic #naaslife

TEXT:
üìì üêç Make your Jupyter notebooks more interactive and user-friendly with IPyWidgets


Why do we use IPyWidgets?
We wanted to create a form to set up tools directly in a notebook instead of having an extra step by using tools like Google Sheets Forms or TypeForms to get information from business users.

So, we associated markdown text and IPyWidgets to create the form directly in a Jupyter Notebook and the result is pretty clean. üòé

TITLE: ü™Ñ Use Jupyter notebooks to building up data pipelines with ‚Äò%run‚Äô magic command in Python in no time.
TEXT:
ü™Ñ Use Jupyter notebooks to building up data pipelines with ‚Äò%run‚Äô magic command in Python in no time.


ü§î Let‚Äôs suppose you are working on a project with several outputs (database, charts, etc..).

üëâ Rather than working on a single Jupyter notebook, you can split your code into various notebooks and create a ‚ÄúPIPELINE‚Äù notebook to execute your workflow with the '%run' Python üêç magic.


It allows you to: 
‚úÖ make your notebooks more readable.
‚úÖ test and validate each notebook independently.
‚úÖ order your pipeline execution.
‚úÖ add new steps in no time.

Did you know this?

TITLE: ‚öôÔ∏è Make your chart more business ready with a company logo with Plotly!
TEXT:
‚öôÔ∏è Make your chart more business ready with a company logo with Plotly! 


If you work with Python, Plotly is the best library to create a nice chart!

The problem is that examples in the documentation do not provide chart business ready for companies. (J√©r√©my Ravenel üòâ)
You need to improve it by adding:
‚û°Ô∏è A white background
‚û°Ô∏è A title
‚û°Ô∏è A legend
üëâ And what about adding your company logo?


Once your graph is created, add the function `fig.add_layout_image()` and set the parameters:
‚úÖ Add your logo URL in `source`
‚úÖ Setup your logo size in `sizex` and `sizey`
‚úÖ Play with the parameters `x` and `y` to display your logo on the top left corner.

TITLE: What are you waiting for to start data science? Are you scared?
TEXT:
What are you waiting for to start data science? Are you scared?
The truth is‚Ä¶


I was scared too. I knew it was an important thing to do in my career but I didn‚Äôt know where to start‚Ä¶ Luckily I had a brother J√©r√©my Ravenel to help me succeed.
Here are the tips he gave me to get started:

‚úÖ Focus on achievable goals
Start working on a simple project that matters to you. Split the project into steps, and appreciate each time go to the next.

‚úÖ Organize your idea before doing anything
For this, I suggest using the simple framework we use at Naas: Input/Model/Output

‚úÖ Google everything
You can literally ask ‚ÄúHow to read excel in python?‚Äù and start from there (sorry my dear üá´üá∑ compatriot, it works best in English).
No need to have prior knowledge of any programming language.

‚úÖ Use Jupyter Notebook Project Jupyter, the most popular data science interface
‚Üí Before, there was only Anaconda distribution, on your computer (some tech setup required)
‚Üí Now, there is naas.ai, on your browser (no setup required) üôàüòá

Naas comes with a bunch of templates that are ready to use, so it‚Äôs even easier to start now.
Check out the link in the first comment,
and let me know what you think?

Thanks a lot üôÇüôèüèª

TITLE: ‚öôÔ∏è Managing DateTime in data is a pain in the aüçëüçë
TEXT:
‚öôÔ∏è Managing DateTime in data is a pain in the aüçëüçë

If you work with Python, DateTime format is your best friend!

With a simple date, you can analyse your data weekly, monthly, quarterly, and beyond.

Mastering it can help you grow your business remarkably. But to achieve it, you need to know how to manipulate it.

I personally spent time learning by myself with the help of many stackoverflow forums. Today, it is time to share some tips about Python with you. üëá


First you need to master d3-time-format in Python.
To do so, I learnt from this useful GitHub documentation https://lnkd.in/e3U3HXVz. We will learn that ‚Äú2021-31-12‚Äù is ‚Äú%Y-%m-%d‚Äù

Then, simply use the formulas (notebooks template‚Äôs are available in first comment):
- to convert a string date to a datetime object to another string date : strptime(date_string, current_format).strftime(new_format)
- to convert pandas series to datetime series to another datetime format : df[col_date] = pd.to_datetime(df[col_date], current_format).dt.strftime(new_format)

Did you know this?

Feel free to share other tips! I am always happy to learn üòÑ üôè


Want more tips? Do not hesitate to like, comment and share this post! Don't forget to star the GitHub repository!

LINKS: https://lnkd.in/e3U3HXVz. We will learn that ‚Äú2021-31-12‚Äù is ‚Äú%Y-%m-%d

TITLE: üí° Data science is about making data useful.
TEXT:
üí° Data science is about making data useful.
And there is a simple way to do that.

Here is how :

I have been working on data science projects for 5+ years, without even knowing it.
I switched from Excel to Python to fix some problems I had, tested a lot of things, failed a lot of times.

But I also learned that it‚Äôs not about coding, it‚Äôs about organizing ideas.

Here is a simple framework that worked every single time.
üëá

-> Define your inputs clearly
List the tools you want to use, how to access them, what are the specific part of the data you want to get.
-> Think about how to model
Define the rules / transformation you want to apply to your data.
-> Design the outputs
A table, a graph, an Excel spreadsheet or an email...think very precisely about what is making sense for you or your audience.

In short, if you work with data, keep this framework in mind :
- Input
- Model
- Output
It will help you see clear and stay focus!

In a next post, I will show you a template on NBA bets done by one of our community members.

I‚Äôm going to try posting more regularly so if you want to support¬†: any like or comment is welcome.‚ö°Ô∏è

See you!

PS: I‚Äôm not alone in this data science journey, the project I‚Äôm working on (naas.ai) is about making the field much more accessible to anyone.

You can join us too, even if you are not a tech - I‚Äôm not üòâ¬†(the link to our Slack is in the first comment)
